author: Nicholas McBride
title: Woman comes home to find runaway mental health patient in her clothes
text:
Woman comes home to find runaway mental health patient in her clothes NICHOLAS MCBRIDE Last updated 21:12, February 7 2017 Warwick Smith/Stuff 
Jen Phillips was shocked to find an intruder sleeping on her couch. 
A Palmerston North woman returned home after a day out to find a runaway mental health patient in her clothes sleeping on her couch. 
Jen Phillips went for a day trip to Wellington on Sunday and returned to find a woman in her house. 
"As I walked in I look over and there is a person staring at me." Warwick Smith/Fairfax NZ 
A security camera in the kitchen sent images of the intruder to Jen Phillips' phone. 
The woman had left Palmerston North Hospital's ward 21 – a mental health unit – and wandered to Phillips' house on Russell St, only a few streets away from the hospital. 
The hospital says the woman had been on a "leave break" and the police were notified when she did not come back. 
Phillips said the woman had gone through her wardrobe and drawers, hung her own pants on the washing line and proceeded to put on Phillips' clothes. Warwick Smith/Fairfax NZ 
Jen Phillips found a runaway mental health patient in her clothes sleeping on her couch. 
"It is disgusting, like what have you touched? Are you coming back? 
"I can't sit here and relax. 
"I want to move. I don't want to be here any more. It is too much." 
The woman broke latches and climbed through her bedroom window and "ransacked" the house, Phillips said. Ad Feedback 
"She took blankets off the bed and made her own little spot on the lounge." 
When Phillips arrived home, the woman said she was waiting for someone, before grabbing a bag and running off. 
"I was like 'what the hell is going on?'" 
Phillips had surveillance cameras on her property and it showed the woman walking past numerous times, as well as playing with the camera once she had broken in. 
"I was looking through [the footage]. It was disturbing. It freaked me out." 
She called the police, who found the woman down the road on Stanley Ave. 
Phillips said she was told by police that she could not press charges because the woman was a mental health patient. 
"I was [fobbed off] and told there was nothing they could do." 
Phillips has had to have a friend stay with her since the break-in. 
"Any little noise, it is terrifying." 
She was glad she got home when she did. 
"If I had come back the next day I think I would have come back to an empty home." 
MidCentral mental health clinical director Syed Ahmer said the woman failed to return from a short period of approved leave. 
"The person in question was on a 15-minute leave break from the ward. When she failed to return, police were notified within 15 minutes. 
"It is very regrettable that the patient allegedly entered someone's property. This is now a police matter and we are unable to comment on it." 
The patient has been returned to the ward. 
Ahmer said leave had an important part to play in treating and rehabilitating people with mental illness. 
"It is used with discretion and is carefully managed. 
"The granting of leave is a clinical judgment, balancing many factors, such as the patient's current state of wellbeing, their progress against their treatment programme, their rights and their responsibilities." 
Acting Manawatu area prevention manager Detective Senior Sergeant Neil Forlong said staff would be talking to Phillips about her options, such as pressing charges. 
Forlong said police were making inquiries into the offending. "Police are meeting with [Phillips on Wednesday] to inform her on the latest in the investigation and provide advice and support. 
"Police encourage anyone who is a victim of crime to lodge a formal complaint with us and we will follow up as appropriate." - Stuff
